I'm also seeing this with the I200505090301 build. However, it does not happen 
if the text file extension is txt. It does happen if the file has no extension 
(e.g. ChangeLog).

I'm seeing this error when running Eclipse 3.1 M7 on Mac OS X 10.4.1.  It shows up when you try to open a 
file (without an extension) in the CDT perspective, as well as the JDT perspective.  However when running 
M7 alone without CDT installed it works fine.

It appears the problem boils down to this:

* without CDT installed,
when you try to open the file, it looks for a content description and doesn't find one (ie 
IFile.getContentDescription() returns null) so it falls back to the default behaviour which opens the file 
as text.

* with CDT installed,
when you try to open the file, it looks for a content description and finds "executable" as the matching 
type.  Before opening the file it verifies the content type and says "oops, this isn't a text file" (ie 
TextFileBufferManager.isTextFileLocation() returns false) and then freaks out and throws an exception.

So the question is then, why does CDT think a plain text file with no extension == executable?

This is one of two-three PR's that stop me from cutting a new ZPU embedded CDT
plugin w/M7.

Created an attachment (id=22114)
removes the default no-extension file association

This patch should hopefully get you out of the mud and back on the road.  It
removes the file association which maps extensionless files to the executable
type.

I wouldn't consider this a fix, however.  The real fix is to implement the
ContentTypeManager stuff.  In this case there would need to be something like a
BinarySignatureDescriber which looks at the file's contents and figures out
whether it is actually binary or text.
